All four productions in Classic Spring‚Äôs starry Oscar Wilde season in the West End can be watched on the online service Marquee TV, which is offering a 14-day free trial. Edward and Freddie Fox play father and son in An Ideal Husband; Eve Best is a memorable Mrs Arbuthnot in A Woman of No Importance; Kathy Burke directs Lady Windermere‚Äôs Fan; and Sophie Thompson is horrified by theatre‚Äôs most famous handbag in The Importance of Being Earnest.

Ghost Quartet

If you missed its run at Soho‚Äôs Boulevard theatre, here‚Äôs a chance to savour Dave Malloy‚Äôs song cycle, filmed in New York in 2015. Alternately rousing and yearning, this is a gorgeous hymn to barflies, precious memories and the joys of being a ghost, told with a dash of Edgar Allan Poe and Thelonious Monk. It‚Äôs a glorious get-together of a show, as warming as the whiskey handed out to the audience ‚Äì but you‚Äôll have to pour your own.

Le Patin Libre

Think dance on ice and you‚Äôd imagine sequins and staggering TV celebrities, but the Canadian troupe, Le Patin Libre, has taken the art form into a new dimension. In their double bill, Vertical Influences, the skaters turned the rink into a mesmerising stage slowly decorated by the patterns cut by their blades. Watch the 20-minute short film Vertical on YouTube.

The School for Wives

Travel restrictions needn‚Äôt prevent you from enjoying international theatre online. Paris‚Äôs esteemed Od√©on has released its 2018 production of Moli√®re‚Äôs satirical 1662 comedy of manners and cuckoldry. Claude Duparfait stars as the foolish Arnolphe, and St√©phane Braunschweig directs. English subtitles available, √©videmment. Read the full review.

5 Soldiers: The Body Is the Frontline

Rosie Kay‚Äôs extraordinary 5 Soldiers: The Body Is the Frontline was staged in army drill halls around the UK, but, since its livestream is still available online, you can watch it from the comfort of your own sofa. Performing in close quarters to a score that mixes punk and opera, Kay‚Äôs phenomenal company bring home the horror of combat and disarm audiences.

The Wind in the Willows

Julian Fellowes, George Stiles and Anthony Drewe teamed up to deliver a merry new version of Kenneth Grahame‚Äôs classic, staged at the London Palladium in 2017, with Rufus Hound wearing 50 shades of green as Mr Toad. It‚Äôs available to rent online, with the option to donate to help provide financial and emotional support to theatre workers.

Girls Like That

London‚Äôs Unicorn theatre has a world-class reputation for theatre for young audiences and its production of Evan Placey‚Äôs Girls Like That gripped the roomful of teenagers I watched it with in 2014. It‚Äôs online in full and offers a raw account of adolescent anxiety, slut-shaming and self-belief. In-your-face theatre that stays in your mind.

John Leguizamo‚Äôs Latin History for Morons

Self-isolation may mean that many of us will use living rooms to both teach children and watch theatre. An opportunity to combine the two can be found courtesy of the super-charismatic John Leguizamo ‚Äì an inspirational tutor if ever there was ‚Äì whose one-man Broadway show, Latin History for Morons, is on Netflix.

Woke

The subscription service LIVR enables you to catch up on theatre in 360-degree virtual reality. Pop your smartphone into a headset they send you and experience a range of shows including Apphia Campbell‚Äôs show Woke, which interweaves the stories of Black Panther Assata Shakur and the 2014 Ferguson riots. The award-winning Patricia Gets Ready, written by Martha Watson Allpress, is also available from LIVR.

Timpson: The Musical

Two households, both alike in dignity ‚Ä¶ well, sort of. Our narrator, a talking portrait, lays our scene in Victorian London, and this musical comedy imagines the founding of the popular shoe-repair chain as a union between two companies, the Montashoes and the Keypulets. Watch Gigglemug Theatre‚Äôs show on their website.

My Left Nut

This is cheating as it‚Äôs a TV series, but BBC Three‚Äôs superb comedy drama is based on one of the most uproarious and affecting fringe theatre shows of recent years. It‚Äôs inspired by Michael Patrick‚Äôs own teenage experience of a medical condition that left his testicle ‚Äúso big you could play it like a bongo‚Äù. Wince.

Rosas Danst Rosas

Love dance? Need to exercise at home? Then join the queen of Belgian avant-garde performance Anne Teresa De Keersmaeker as she talks you through how to perform her 1983 classic, Rosas Danst Rosas. All you need is a chair, a bit of legroom and enough space to swing your hair.
fields.bodyText: Shaw Shorts Paul Miller, artistic director of Richmond‚Äôs Orange Tree theatre, continues his fine run of George Bernard Shaw productions with this pair of one-act plays about desire, How He Lied to Her Husband (1904) and Overruled (1912). The 70-minute double bill runs at the Orange Tree until 26 June but will be livestreamed on 3 and 4 June. Read the full review. Paradise Lost (Lies Unopened Beside Me) Did Milton‚Äôs biblical epic escape your lockdown reading list of classics? Fear not: Ben Duke returns with his celebrated one-man version, created with his Lost Dog company and presented by the Place. Duke performs live on 5 June and it‚Äôs available again on 6 June. Duke‚Äôs show is for the ages ‚Äì funny, profound, inspiring and soaked with as much a sense of loss as creation, a reminder that Milton was in mourning for his wife when he wrote the poem. Shakespeare‚Äôs Globe If you can‚Äôt get into the Wooden O for its new summer season then fear not: most of the shows are being streamed. There‚Äôs a revival of the carnivalesque 2019 Midsummer Night‚Äôs Dream, director Ola Ince‚Äôs eagerly awaited Romeo and Juliet, and Twelfth Night with artistic director Michelle Terry as Viola. The Globe Player also has heaps of past productions to rent, including an international selection from the 2012 Globe to Globe festival such as a Lithuanian Hamlet, a Japanese Coriolanus and an Armenian King John. There is also the candlelit Sam Wanamaker Playhouse‚Äôs opening production, The Duchess of Malfi, starring Gemma Arterton. Fleabag You‚Äôve watched both TV series. You‚Äôve read the scripts. Maybe you‚Äôve even seen the stage show more than once. But you‚Äôll probably still be streaming Phoebe Waller-Bridge‚Äôs performance of her wildly successful monologue, recorded at Wyndham‚Äôs theatre in London, where it sold out in the summer of 2019. Fleabag is available to stream from Amazon Prime, as part of a partnership with the National Theatre that includes three other NT Live favourites: Hamlet with Benedict Cumberbatch; Frankenstein with Cumberbatch and Jonny Lee Miller and Ian McKellen‚Äôs 80th-birthday solo show. All available from 11 June. Drowntown Rhiannon Faith‚Äôs dance-theatre productions have tackled tough subjects in bold and surprising ways: her fringe show Scary Shit wormed its way into the brain with its mix of troubling and comforting images. Faith‚Äôs new piece is built around autobiographical testimonies of isolation and research into the challenges faced by coastal towns with underfunded services, presenting ‚Äúa society at tipping point‚Äù. Performed by a cast of six including the phenomenal Shelley Eva Haden. Available from 1-30 June. Dep Previously seen at Edinburgh fringe‚Äôs Zoo Southside in 2018, this award-winning physical theatre show about death and rebirth is choreographed by Dam Van Huynh and takes its name from the Vietnamese word for beautiful. When the Guardian asked its multinational cast to describe the work in just one word they answered ‚Äúresilience‚Äù, ‚Äúhuman‚Äù, ‚Äúintrospective‚Äù and ‚Äúalive‚Äù. One added that it‚Äôs ‚Äúan eyeful‚Äù ‚Äì after all, it‚Äôs performed fully naked. Available until 3June as part of the Arts Institute Plymouth‚Äôs Making It season. Footprints festival Jermyn Street theatre is streaming its reopening festival, crammed with more than 40 shows, including monologues, two-handers, cabaret and poetry. Highlights include Ade Morris‚Äôs drama about aviator Amy Johnson, Lone Flyer, which received rave reviews at the Watermill, and a revival of Mr and Mrs Nobody, Keith Waterhouse‚Äôs spin on George and Weedon Grossmith‚Äôs diary of finicky clerk Mr Pooter. The season opens with Biyi Bandele‚Äôs award-winner Two Horsemen. Festival runs until 1 August. Read the review of Two Horsemen. Decades: Stories from the City Leeds Playhouse marks its 50th birthday with six new monologues, each depicting Yorkshire life in a different decade, from Simon Armitage‚Äôs 70s-set drama set against the terror caused by Peter Sutcliffe to Stan Owens‚Äô modern-day piece about a carer in lockdown. With other pieces by Alice Nutter, Maxine Peake, Leanna Benjamin and Kamal Kaan, and staged by a top-notch set of directors, it‚Äôs a birthday party that‚Äôs not to be missed. Until 5 June. Touchy Originally designed as a gig-theatre stage show before the pandemic, this project from 20 Stories High was commissioned by the Wellcome Collection to explore the importance of touch for young people. The theme took on new resonance in our world of social distancing and the show has spawned five homemade short films instead, created by emerging Liverpool artists. The films are released weekly, with the complete series available on 10 June. Royal Ballet The Royal Opera House has worked wonders during the pandemic to open up new, live performances and past productions for an audience at home. Its current offerings include an evening of George Balanchine and Jerome Robbins (available from 11 June-11 July) and its grand reopening show, 21st-Century Choreographers, which features Christopher Wheeldon‚Äôs sumptuous Within the Golden Hour, a new duet by American star choreographer Kyle Abraham and two shows, The Statement and Solo Echo, by the Canadian dance-theatre sensation Crystal Pite. 21st-Century Choreographers is available until 27 June. Read the full review. Ad Libido Around a third of young and middle-aged women suffer from a form of sexual dysfunction. Not everyone feels able to talk about it but Fran Bushe put her experiences centre-stage with Ad Libido, a solo comedy theatre show about the problems she had with desire, orgasm and pain during sex. Bush has since written a short Channel 4 comedy and a novel, My Broken Vagina, and is taking the show back to Soho theatre in late summer. But you can also stream it until 19 June via Oxford‚Äôs Old Fire Station. Touching the Void Bristol Old Vic brings back its nail-biting 2018 hit show based on Joe Simpson‚Äôs 1988 mountaineering memoir, adapted by David Greig, directed by Tom Morris and featuring an awe-inspiring set design by Ti Green. It‚Äôs staged live before a theatre audience, using binaural technology and multiple cameras. Watch on demand 2-8 June. Read the five-star review. MTFestUK 2021 Get a first glimpse of eight new musicals in this festival, which just may include the next West End smash. There‚Äôs an adaptation of Todd Haynes‚Äô melodrama Far from Heaven, a grime musical set in 1641, an R&B tale about Marie Antoinette, a Tony Blair rock opera, and the tale of a snow leopard, an elephant and an orangutan who form a rock band to protest against the climate crisis. After a two-week run on stage at London‚Äôs Turbine theatre, the festival goes online. Until 4 July. Lit Sophie Ellerby‚Äôs slow-burning drama about looking for love and the fear of being left behind is set over the summer holidays bridging Years 9 and 10 in a Nottingham secondary school. Full of insights about teenagers‚Äô initiations to adulthood, it was a revelation at Aldeburgh‚Äôs HighTide festival in 2019. Now filmed, it is available on demand from 1-29 June as part of Nottingham Playhouse‚Äôs Spring Loaded season, which includes Still Life: Untold Stories from Nottingham Now, a collection of short films featuring a new vignette by Alan Bennett; the dystopian audio drama Oh for F*ck‚Äôs Sake (I‚Äôm in Love With You) by Samson Hawkins; and First Touch, Nathaniel Price‚Äôs play about football‚Äôs child sex abuse scandal. Sound Stage What do you miss about theatre? If it‚Äôs not only the plays but also the preshow buzz, interval chatter with friends and postshow discussions then you‚Äôre not alone. Sound Stage is a new digital initiative from Pitlochry Festival theatre and the Royal Lyceum in collaboration with Naked Productions. It aims to recreate elements of the social experience of theatregoing, complete with a virtual bar where visitors can mingle. The opening season of audio plays brings together eight fantastic writers: Mark Ravenhill, Timberlake Wertenbaker, Roy Williams, John Byrne, Jaimini Jethwa, Lynda Radley, Gary McNair and Frances Poet. Home: Part One In January, the Commission of Investigation into Mother and Baby Homes published its long-awaited report on the ‚Äúappalling‚Äù abuse at mother and baby institutions run by both the state and the Catholic church in Ireland. This devastating series of dramatised readings, directed by Graham McLaren and Neil Murray, gives voice to those experiences, with testimonies ‚Äì and extracts from the report ‚Äì read on stage by actors and some of the survivors themselves. Available until 17 July. Read more. BBC Lights Up The BBC‚Äôs virtual theatre festival offers 18 newly recorded productions for TV, radio and online. The Royal Shakespeare Company‚Äôs new version of The Winter‚Äôs Tale is directed by Erica Whyman. Yasmin Joseph‚Äôs play J‚ÄôOuvert, part of a forthcoming springtime West End season, is available and there‚Äôs also David Ireland‚Äôs searing new play Sadie and a TV adaptation of Orpheus in the Record Shop, a collaboration between Opera North and Leeds Playhouse written by rapper and playwright Testament. Radio plays include The Meaning of Zong, the debut play written by Giles Terera. Further details. One Hand Tied Behind Us The Old Vic celebrates International Women‚Äôs Day by rereleasing a selection of the monologues curated by Maxine Peake in 2018 to mark 100 years since the Representation of the People Act. The pieces are written by Peake, Ella Hickson, Kit de Waal and Jeanette Winterson. There are also two new monologues: standup Kiri Pritchard-McLean‚Äôs Putting a Face On is about gaslighting and stars Susan Wokoma, while Regina Taylor‚Äôs Aisha (the black album) traces the history of black women‚Äôs political power and is performed by Jade Anouka. Musicals: The Greatest Show With dozens of stars and thousands of spotlights, Sheridan Smith hosts a celebration of musical theatre at the London Palladium. Smith performs Don‚Äôt Rain on My Parade from Funny Girl, the queens of West End smash-hit Six perform in the balcony and there are songs from Dear Evan Hansen, Everybody‚Äôs Talking About Jamie, Dreamgirls and more, plus Nicole Scherzinger (in rather fabulous earrings) beams in from LA with a brilliant rendition of Never Enough from The Greatest Showman. Available all year on BBC iPlayer. The Macbeths Director Dominic Hill and writer Frances Poet slashed down Shakespeare‚Äôs tragedy to create a gripping two-hander thriller staged at the Citizens theatre in Glasgow in 2017. Now it‚Äôs a 60-minute film that unfolds in and around the murderous couple‚Äôs bed. Charlene Boyd and Keith Fleming reprise their roles. From 3 June. Barnes‚Äô People He is best known for The Ruling Class but many of Peter Barnes‚Äôs plays are overdue a revival; so here‚Äôs an attractive proposition from Original Theatre Company and Perfectly Normal Productions. It‚Äôs a set of four monologues Barnes wrote for Radio 3 in the 80s and includes True Born Englishman, about a Buckingham Palace footman, which was never aired by the BBC and now gets its world premiere. Filmed on stage at the Theatre Royal Windsor, the monologues are performed by Jon Culshaw, Matthew Kelly, Jemma Redgrave and Adrian Scarborough. Streaming until 31 July. Read the full review. The Merthyr Stigmatist A 16-year-old girl in the Welsh valleys claims to have received the wounds of Christ in Lisa Parry‚Äôs new play, which is given a fully staged digital production in Cardiff‚Äôs Sherman studio theatre. A co-production with Theatre Uncut, directed by Emma Callander, Parry‚Äôs play was originally scheduled as part of the Sherman‚Äôs autumn season last year and was shortlisted for the inaugural Theatre Uncut political playwriting award. Available until 12 June. Read the full review. Really Want to Hurt Me Written and directed by Ben SantaMaria for his company Flaming Theatre, this monologue charts how pop music and theatre keep a young gay teenager afloat as he experiences bullying and isolation in 80s Devon. It‚Äôs performed by Ryan Price at Theatre503 in London in 2018, filmed by My Reel Productions, before the show went on an acclaimed UK tour. Northern Ballet Yorkshire‚Äôs high-flying ballet company presents a pay-what-you-can digital season including short new premieres and the full version of Cathy Marston‚Äôs acclaimed regal spectacular Victoria. Choreographer Kenneth Tindall and film-maker Dan Lowenstein collaborate on Northern Lights, which brings dancers to the streets of Leeds, and Tindall‚Äôs Have Your Cake takes inspiration from the nation baking banana bread in lockdown. Ballet Black‚Äôs Mthuthuzeli November presents What Used To, No Longer Is, choreographed and created entirely remotely. National Theatre at Home After the success of its weekly Thursday night streams during lockdown, the NT launched a catalogue of past hits online. You can either become a subscriber, or pay per play. Titles include The Deep Blue Sea starring the late Helen McCrory; Tony Kushner‚Äôs two-part epic Angels in America; Antigone starring two time lords, Christopher Eccleston and Jodie Whittaker; and Behind the Beautiful Forevers, based on the book by Katherine Boo and starring Meera Syal. There are classics such as Ph√®dre with Helen Mirren, Amadeus with Lucian Msamati, and the Donmar‚Äôs Coriolanus with Tom Hiddleston, as well as new writing, including Lucy Kirkwood‚Äôs Mosquitoes and Shahid Hadeem‚Äôs Dara. New plays are added to the collection each month. Uncle Vanya Ian Rickson‚Äôs indelible production of Chekhov‚Äôs masterpiece, in a new version by Conor McPherson, was a West End sensation at the start of 2020. After it closed early due to the pandemic, Rickson and producer Sonia Friedman reunited most of the cast for this innovative filmed version. Each performance rings true ‚Äì from Toby Jones in the title role to Aimee Lou Wood‚Äôs Sonya, Richard Armitage‚Äôs Astrov and the always excellent Rosalind Eleazar as Yelena. And Bruno Poet‚Äôs lighting and Rae Smith‚Äôs set design combine to spellbinding effect. On BBC iPlayer. Earwig With the stage out of bounds, theatre-makers are devising ever more creative sonic experiments to be enjoyed at home. Directed by Finn den Hertog and composed and sound-designed by Danny Krass, Earwig is billed as a series of ‚Äúaudio drama podcasts‚Äù from the Tron in Glasgow. There are half a dozen of them, written by playwrights based in Scotland, including Stef Smith, Hannah Lavery and Jo Clifford. Designed to be listened to on headphones. Read the full review. Typical In 2019, Richard Blackwood gave a compelling performance at the Edinburgh fringe and Soho theatre in a monologue retelling the story of British-Nigerian Christopher Alder, the decorated paratrooper from Hull who died while handcuffed on the floor of a Humberside police station in 1998. Now, the acclaimed play by Ryan Calais Cameron has been turned into a film directed by Anastasia Osei-Kuffour. It explores, says the playwright, ‚Äúthe negotiations that black people need to make in order to do things that seem simple to others‚Äù. Read the five-star review. The Inquest Fancy solving a crime from your sofa? This piece of puzzle theatre invites audiences to crack clues with strangers ‚Äì or you can arrange a private show to team up with your pals. Viewers turned jurors are presented with a tangled web of evidence from a cold case and assisted through their deliberations by the performers Joe Ball (as a coroner) and Tom Black (as a police archivist). It‚Äôs the second creation from Jury Games whose debut, Jury Duty, is still available online. Read the full review. Myths and Adventures from Ancient Greece If home-schooling feels like opening a Pandora‚Äôs box, well, here‚Äôs a fun way to help your kids engage with the Greek myths on the curriculum. Hannah Khalil has created new versions of the tales of Pandora, Persephone, King Midas and Theseus and the Minotaur. They‚Äôre intended for those aged three to eight but will appeal to older viewers, too. Available on YouTube from Waterman‚Äôs Arts Centre, they are staged by the director Ian Nicholson and designer Sam Wilde, who brightened up lockdown with their delightful puppet versions of the picture books I Want My Hat Back and Shh! We Have a Plan. Shipwreck First staged at the Almeida in 2019, Shipwreck by Anne ‚ÄúMr Burns‚Äù Washburn gave a sprawling account of modern-day American politics and the rise and potential fall of Trump. It was due to be staged at the Public theatre in New York in 2020 but was instead adapted by Saheem Ali as a three-part audio play in a co-production with Woolly Mammoth theatre company. Set during a getaway for a bunch of friends in upstate New York in 2017, it‚Äôs a knotty appraisal of an American moment that, strikingly, already feels like a vanishing era. What the Constitution Means to Me Heidi Schreck‚Äôs phenomenal Broadway show has received five-star reviews from Guardian critics on both sides of the Atlantic. Now available to stream from Amazon, it charts what the supreme law of the US has meant to generations of women, as Schreck recreates the debating competitions she took part in as a teenager. Directed by Marielle Heller, it‚Äôs shatteringly funny, deeply disturbing yet imbued with optimism. The Cost of Living As a tribute to the acclaimed disabled dancer David Toole, who died in October, the physical theatre company DV8 have shared their multi-award-winning 2004 film The Cost of Living online. Shot on location at a faded seaside resort in Norfolk, it follows two street performers (Toole and Eddie Kay) in a portrait of friendship and prejudice, brimming with spellbinding images. Available on DV8‚Äôs Media Portal for a small membership fee. Unmissable. Pippin They‚Äôve got magic to do, just for you: the original 1980 Broadway production of the Tony award-winning musical, with catchy songs by Stephen Schwartz and some glorious moves by Bob Fosse, is available to stream on Amazon. Ben Vereen is the beguiling leading player of a troupe who may or may not lead the eponymous prince to self-immolation. It‚Äôs bizarre and frequently frustrating, but a fascinating chapter of Broadway history. Get the backstage view in the series Fosse/Verdon on BBC iPlayer. The York Mystery Plays This pandemic year has seen a boom in sales for classic fiction as we finally get round to reading famous ‚Äúbucket list‚Äù novels. Why not do the same for theatre ‚Äì and why not start with some of the York Mystery Plays, which date back to the 1300s? Four of the biblical dramas, including the story of Adam and Eve, have been adapted for BBC radio, with a cast of community and professional actors for York Theatre Royal‚Äôs Collective Acts project. An American in Paris Feted at the Ch√¢telet in Paris in 2014, Christopher Wheeldon‚Äôs resplendent staging of the Gershwins‚Äô classic went on to conquer Broadway and the West End. It‚Äôs available on a new streaming platform, Stage2View.com, which also offers the musicals Kinky Boots and 42nd Street, as well as Michael Grandage‚Äôs Mark Rothko drama Red, starring Alfred Molina as the artist. User Not Found When we die, what becomes of our digital identity? Do all those tweets and posts endure for eternity ‚Äì and who decides? The site-specific theatre company Dante or Die asked such questions, and many more, in a thoughtful and funny 2018 show by Chris Goode that was staged in cafes. It has now been reimagined as a 50-minute video podcast, available from the Guardian until 31 March 2022. Flight Paths This production by the theatre company Extant celebrates the rich history of Goze, itinerant blind performers who traditionally travelled around Japan to bring audiences a vast selection of stories ‚Äì accompanied by music played on their shamisen stringed instruments. Flight Paths fuses old and new, bringing together archive material about the Goze, animation and filmed modern performance, in an accessible hour-long digital experience. good dog Arinz√© Kene‚Äôs poetic 2017 play good dog posed unanswered questions about the UK‚Äôs summer riots of 2011. Revived for a tour last year, it has now been adapted as a superb 20-minute film, directed by Andrew Gillman and Natalie Ibu for Tiata Fahodzi. Anton Cross stars as a man looking back on his youth, his neighbours and his community. The film was commissioned by The Space and supported by the BBC and Arts Council England. Charlotte Holmes: Adventure Box Lockdown restrictions and cancelled travel plans have narrowed horizons for little adventurers. So this ‚Äúseven-day theatrical experience‚Äù for families is both a delight and a relief. Created by Huddersfield‚Äôs Lawrence Batley theatre, the Dukes in Lancaster and theatre producers the Big Tiny, it‚Äôs a series of mysteries encountered by Charlotte, a young girl evacuated to Yorkshire during the second world war. You solve the puzzles by watching jaunty online videos and opening up the envelopes and parcels inside an adventure box sent to you in the post when you book. The Big Tiny‚Äôs follow-up, Balthazar Snapdragon, is just as fun. Read the full review. Hamilton Lin-Manuel Miranda‚Äôs phenomenal, Pulitzer prize-winning musical about the ‚Äú10-dollar founding father without a father‚Äù was filmed over three nights in New York in 2016 with the original Broadway cast. Slated for a 2021 cinema release, it was instead fast-tracked on to the Disney+ streaming service. It‚Äôs directed by Thomas Kail, who staged the musical, and according to Miranda gives ‚Äúeveryone the best seat in the house‚Äù. Watch it once and, to quote Jonathan Groff‚Äôs frothing King George III, You‚Äôll Be Back. Read the full, five-star review. As Waters Rise Ben Weatherill‚Äôs play is set in the year 2025 when a flood has left Britain in a state of emergency. Originally planned for a stage production, it is now a three-part audio drama directed by Alex Brown and featuring teenage actors from the Almeida Young Company, who recorded their parts in isolation during lockdown. Released as part of Shifting Tides, the Almeida‚Äôs digital festival about the climate emergency, aimed at and created with 14- to 25-year-olds. Read the full review. Culture in Quarantine The BBC‚Äôs Culture in Quarantine programme on iPlayer includes Jade Anouka and Grace Savage‚Äôs Her & Her; Crystal Pite and Jonathon Young‚Äôs five-star show Revisor; Where I Go (When I Can‚Äôt Be Where I Am), about living with chronic pain, conceived and directed by Rachel Bagshaw and written by Chris Thorpe; Corey Baker‚Äôs marvellous mini Swan Lake, performed in dancers‚Äô baths; and Open Clasp theatre company‚Äôs Sugar, devised with women who are homeless, on probation or in prison. First, Do No Harm Sharon D Clarke has portrayed a long line of memorable characters but this is something else. In a new short play by Bernardine Evaristo, directed by Adrian Lester, Clarke speaks for the National Health Service and those who work for it, reflecting on the NHS‚Äôs past and future. As she proudly says: ‚ÄúI am one of the best things that has ever happened.‚Äù First, Do No Harm is part of a series celebrating the NHS entitled The Greatest Wealth, curated for the Old Vic by Lolita Chakrabarti. The Old Vic is also pioneering socially distanced live performances and rehearsed readings as well as archive recordings of past productions. Nine Lives Slam poet and playwright Zodwa Nyoni was born in Zimbabwe and grew up in Yorkshire. The locations are combined in her vivid 2016 monologue, in which Lladel Bryant plays Ishmael, a young gay Zimbabwean who flees homophobic violence in his home country and seeks asylum in the UK where he is dispersed to Leeds. Alex Chisholm‚Äôs hour-long production, available on YouTube, was recorded at the Arcola theatre in London. The Lord Chamberlain‚Äôs Men The all-male theatre company, known for touring open-air Shakespeare productions around the UK, has postponed its Macbeth until next year but shared two past productions on YouTube and on their website: The Tempest, staged in 2018, and A Midsummer Night‚Äôs Dream, presented last year to mark the company‚Äôs 15th birthday. They encourage you to recreate the spirit of their productions at home ‚Äì ‚Äúwhether it is on a picnic blanket in your living room or under the stars wrapped up warm‚Äù ‚Äì and share the results on social media. Richard II Quite simply one of 2019‚Äôs most celebrated and momentous stagings of Shakespeare. Adjoa Andoh stars as Richard and co-directs, with Lynette Linton, a superb cast entirely comprising women of colour including Shobna Gulati and Ayesha Dharker. An English history play vividly staged for today in the Globe‚Äôs candlelit Sam Wanamaker Playhouse, perfect for a play full of plotting. Available on YouTube. WeRNotVirus Directed by Jennifer Tang and Anthony Lau, this series of 10 short dramas by Moongate Productions and Omnibus theatre explores the pandemic of racism exacerbated by Covid-19 and enacted against Britain‚Äôs east and south-east Asian communities. With pieces by writers including Oladipo Agboluaje, Nemo Martin and Lucy Chau Lai-Tuen, it amounts to two hours of theatre on film that incorporates animation, poetry, music and dance. Some catchup videos are available on YouTube. Read the full review. Audible Amazon‚Äôs audiobook service includes a range of drama, such as Until the Flood by Dael Orlandersmith and a five-play collection from 2019‚Äôs Edinburgh fringe that includes Alan Harris‚Äôs NHS drama For All I Care. There‚Äôs also a chance to catch versions of memoirs you may have missed on stage, such as Vanessa Redgrave performing Joan Didion‚Äôs The Year of Magical Thinking and Maxine Peake‚Äôs version of Julia Leigh‚Äôs Avalanche: A Love Story. Plus: Emma Thompson and Sinead Matthews play Edith Sitwell and Marilyn Monroe respectively in a new play, The Dame and the Showgirl, by Simon Berry. Scenes for Survival The National Theatre of Scotland was among the first theatres to announce a lockdown programme of work responding to the pandemic. Its growing collection of short films is designed to offer audiences ‚Äúhope and joy‚Äù. There‚Äôs Brian Cox as Ian Rankin‚Äôs Edinburgh detective John Rebus, Two Doors Down‚Äôs Jonathan Watson as a shipyard electrician suffering from exposure to asbestos, and Kate Dickie as brilliant as ever in a monologue by Jenni Fagan. The lineup of Scottish talent is extraordinary ‚Äì Tam Dean Burn, Rona Munro and Douglas Henshall all contribute ‚Äì and don‚Äôt miss Janey Godley‚Äôs two-hander with her adorable sausage dog. Read the full review. Unprecedented How‚Äôs this for a lineup? The cast includes Katherine Parkinson, Paterson Joseph and Denise Gough. This is a short but profound show, directed by Lee Lyford, hatched by the Egg theatre‚Äôs Incubator development programme and cleverly designed by Anisha Fields. Read the full review. Lyric theatre in Belfast Belfast‚Äôs Lyric had to cancel its co-production of 1984 with Bruiser Theatre Company but instead launched the initiative New Speak: Re-imagined, in which Northern Irish talents including Amadan Ensemble, Dominic Montague and Katie Richardson respond to the lockdown crisis. Offerings include the ‚Äúfantastically witty‚Äù Wasted, a rock musical about the Bront√´s, directed by Adam Lenson with music by Christopher Ash and book and lyrics by Carl Miller. There‚Äôs also a Twelfth Night relocated to a music festival, directed by Anna Girvan, and Jesse Briton‚Äôs Bound, about a maritime tragedy. English National Ballet Tamara Rojo‚Äôs brilliant company has a steadily growing catalogue of productions, available as individual three-day rentals. There‚Äôs Akram Khan‚Äôs breathtaking Dust, about the first world war; his version of Giselle with Rojo in the lead role; and classics such as Alina Cojocaru and Vadim Muntagirov starring in the swashbuckler Le Corsaire. Rent from ENB. Royal Shakespeare Company Our revels have temporarily ended in theatres but you can watch a groundbreaking effects-laden version of The Tempest, with Simon Russell Beale as Prospero, with a subscription (or 14-day free trial) to the online service Marquee TV. Schaub√ºhne The celebrated Berlin theatre, run by Thomas Ostermeier, is streaming a selection of archive productions, many with English subtitles, and often for one night only. It‚Äôs a rare opportunity for UK audiences to see works directed by Luc Bondy and Ostermeier himself. This month‚Äôs lineup. Alexander Ekman Five works by the Swedish choreographer are on Marquee TV, including a new work for the Royal Swedish Ballet, Eskapist, which got a five-star review from Lyndsey Winship. On a vast stage, ‚ÄúEkman offers a bombardment of fantastical images, realised with the help of Danish fashion designer Henrik Vibskov, who does a Mad Hatter‚Äôs couture party of eccentrically structured silhouettes.‚Äù Ekman‚Äôs other works to rent include Swan Lake and Midsummer Night‚Äôs Dream. Read the full review. What the Butler Saw Joe Orton‚Äôs final farce, completed in the summer of 1967 just before the playwright‚Äôs death, is a subversive satire about an irrational world, set in a psychiatrist‚Äôs consulting room. Rufus Hound dons the white coat as the philandering Dr Prentice in Nikolai Foster‚Äôs 2017 production for Leicester Curve and Theatre Royal Bath. The cast includes Dakota Blue Richards and Jasper Britton. Curve‚Äôs productions of Memoirs of an Asian Football Casual and The Importance of Being Earnest are also online. The Phantom of the Opera Obsession! Haunting ballads! A shattered chandelier! And musical theatre‚Äôs most famous mask ‚Ä¶ Enjoy one of the world‚Äôs most successful shows, presented at the Royal Albert Hall in 2011, with Ramin Karimloo as the Phantom and Sierra Boggess as Christine, to celebrate its 25th anniversary. The film is available to rent on Amazon. It was also streamed as part of The Shows Must Go On, a series offering a different Andrew Lloyd Webber musical each week. The Swan Birmingham Royal Ballet‚Äôs new director Carlos Acosta has reworked The Dying Swan (originally choreographed by Mikhail Fokine for Anna Pavlova), and BRB principal dancer C√©line Gittens performs the piece from her living room to yours. Camille Saint-Sa√´ns‚Äôs Le Cygne, from Le Carnaval des Animaux, is performed by pianist Jonathan Higgins and cellist Antonio Novais. ‚ÄúThis is a dance of promises,‚Äù says Acosta. Now, they are streaming this ambitious show in which a cast of actors remake George Romero‚Äôs classic horror film shot by shot in real time. The company have also opened up their archive to stream a selection of creations from the last 20 years, available on a pay-what-you-like basis. Now I‚Äôm Fine What better time is there to watch a ‚Äúgrand-scale experimental pop opera about keeping it together‚Äù? Ahamefule J Oluo‚Äôs innovative show, staged at Seattle‚Äôs Moore theatre in 2014, mixes standup-style routines with a mesmerising musical accompaniment and explores his experience of a rare autoimmune disease. It is one of many films, including Americana Kamikaze, that are available to rent or buy from On the Boards. Read the full review. Filmed at the Push festival in Home, Manchester, YESYESNONO‚Äôs production is an open, affecting and troubling look at searching for intimacy and connection. This hour will leave you re-evaluating your own life. I, Cinna The outbreak of home-schooling caused by the coronavirus has found many of us playing the role of teacher while still in our dressing gowns. And here‚Äôs one unexpected tutor who really commands your attention: Jude Owusu, clad in a dirty bathrobe, with a pen behind his ear and a notepad dangling around his neck. Owusu is Cinna, the poet from Julius Caesar, in this spellbinding film of Tim Crouch‚Äôs monologue. Read the full review. Alonzo King Lines Ballet A handful of productions by San Francisco-based choreographer Alonzo King and his marvellous company Lines Ballet are available to rent on Marquee TV. Dust and Light, Triangle of the Squinches and Scheherazade, all filmed in 2012, showcase the elegant nature of his work, which pushes beyond classical ballet. Read the full review. Funny Girl Showtunes don‚Äôt get much more defiant or rousing than Don‚Äôt Rain on My Parade. Sheridan Smith wards off the clouds with a gritty rendition as Fanny Bryce in this production of the classic musical at Manchester‚Äôs Palace theatre in 2017. It‚Äôs one of the many productions available to rent from Digital Theatre, whose offerings also include The Crucible starring Richard Armitage at the Old Vic in London, and Maxine Peake‚Äôs Hamlet at the Royal Exchange in Manchester. Paris‚Äôs esteemed Od√©on has released its 2018 production of Moli√®re‚Äôs satirical 1662 comedy of manners and cuckoldry. fields.headline: Malaysia struggling to contain sharp rise in Covid cases
fields.standfirst:
Country to enter near-total lockdown after record daily cases for five consecutive days

  • Coronavirus ‚Äì latest updates
  • See all our coronavirus coverage
fields.trailText: Country to enter near-total lockdown after record daily cases for five consecutive days
fields.body:
Malaysia‚Äôs intensive care units are struggling to cope with a sharp rises in Covid cases, the health director general has warned, as the country prepares to enter a near total lockdown from Tuesday.

Malaysia managed to avoid the worst of the pandemic last year, but has struggled to contain a recent outbreak that has been driven by more infectious variants of the virus, and exacerbated by gatherings ahead of Eid al-Fitr.

This month alone, more than 1,200 deaths have been recorded, compared with 471 during the whole of 2020. Last week, Malaysia reported record daily cases for five consecutive days and announced its highest daily rise since the start of the pandemic on Saturday, when 9,020 new infections were reported.

Related: South-east Asian countries battle Covid resurgence amid lack of vaccines

The health director general, Noor Hisham Abdullah, said that although extra ICU beds had been created, some facilities had already reached full capacity. ‚ÄúThis has led to patients being treated in normal wards,‚Äù he said in a statement on Facebook on Sunday. The surge in cases over the weekend meant that the number of patients with severe illness was expected to rise further, he added.

Additional containers have also been sent to hospital morgues, which are struggling to cope with the rise in deaths.

Under new lockdown rules, which will be introduced on Tuesday, only two people from each household will be allowed to go out to buy essentials or seek medical treatment within 10km of their home. Sports activities such as jogging that do not involve physical contact are permitted but only between 7am and 8pm. Schools and shopping malls will be shut.

Much of the manufacturing sector will be allowed to continue operating with a reduced workforce. This includes companies producing rubber gloves, electronics, oil and gas, chemical products and food and beverages.

Malaysia is among several south-east Asian countries, including Thailand and Singapore, that managed to keep the virus under control last year, but which have reported sudden increases in cases. The region is facing new, more infectious variants but is struggling to roll out vaccination campaigns quickly.

The Malaysian government has said it will to set up five more mass vaccination centres in the capital, Kuala Lumpur, and that private doctors will join immunisation efforts to boost capacity. So far, almost 6% of the country‚Äôs 32 million population have received at least one vaccine dose. The government reached 107,000 doses a day last week and aims to increase daily vaccinations to 150,000 doses.

Human rights groups have warned that Malaysia‚Äôs health campaigns are likely to be hindered by its hostile treatment of migrants and refugees. The immigration department announced it will carry out raids and surprise checks throughout the two-week lockdown.

Many migrants are fearful of coming forward to access medical care, even though the government has announced that all people will qualify for vaccines, regardless of their immigration status, said John Quinley, senior human rights specialist for the NGO Fortify Rights.

‚ÄúThose are well-founded fears ‚Äì of people being sent back to countries of origin that have ongoing war and persecution, or of just not being able to economically provide for your family because you‚Äôve been put in detention,‚Äù he said.

Last year, Malaysia arrested thousands of migrants and held them in overcrowded detention centres, which subsequently experienced outbreaks of the virus. It is feared that additional arrests will only lead to further clusters inside cramped facilities.

fields.headline: The Plague Year: America in the Time of Covid review ‚Äì a devastating analysis
fields.standfirst: Lawrence Wright‚Äôs deep research reveals the oversights and errors that fatally hampered the US reponse to Covid
fields.trailText: Lawrence Wright‚Äôs deep research reveals the oversights and errors that fatally hampered the US reponse to Covid
fields.body:
It has become an embarrassingly well known fact that in the 2019 Global Health Security Index, the US was ranked No 1 in the world for preparedness for a pandemic (the UK, almost as embarrassingly, was No 2). Exactly how the US became the worst affected country in the world ‚Äì more than 590,000 Americans have so far died from Covid ‚Äì is now the subject of much finger-pointing debate.

Recently, Michael Lewis‚Äôs Premonition looked at a group of people in public health in the US who warned of what was coming but were ignored. Lawrence Wright, who is a master of knitting together complex narratives, takes a much broader view of the proceedings in The Plague Year.

Renowned for his careful research, Wright starts where the virus began: China. In all the noise and controversy that followed Donald Trump‚Äôs distraction tactic of referring to Covid-19 as the ‚ÄúChina virus‚Äù, it can be forgotten that China wilfully withheld crucial information from the world for the better part of a month. And this at a stage when full disclosure could well have led to a far less catastrophic outcome, both in terms of mortality and the economy.

Nor does Wright shy away from identifying the compromised role of the World Health Organization, which took China‚Äôs word that there was no evidence of a communicable disease when in fact all the available evidence pointed at a new and lethal virus.

It‚Äôs important to restate these entirely avoidable failures because China has form in this field and there is every reason to believe that lessons have not been learned. The country is home to at least 147 species of bats, which in turn are home to hundreds of different coronaviruses. Both Sars and Sars-CoV-2, the virus that causes Covid-19, are thought to have originated in bats and only a blind optimist would ignore the possibility of history repeating itself.

Trump went so far as to rally support for the fight against Covid by visiting a mask factory ‚Äì while not wearing a mask!

Unfortunately for America, it happened to be governed by a blind optimist when Covid hit its shores. When the virus was first identified in the US, Trump told the World Economic Forum in Davos that it was ‚Äúunder control‚Äù. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs going to be just fine,‚Äù he declared.

Trump actually made a couple of decent early decisions in shutting down travel from China and Europe, contrary to public health advice. But pretty much everything else he did seemed designed to sabotage his nation‚Äôs efforts to combat the spread of the virus.

He set individual states to bid against each other for PPE, as though they were procuring it from eBay. He ignored his government‚Äôs advice and almost certainly became a super-spreader of the virus within the White House. And, as Wright reminds us, he even went so far as to rally support for the fight against Covid by visiting a mask factory ‚Äì while not wearing a mask!

He also appointed questionable officials who ended up running critical health institutions during the pandemic. Robert Redfield, for example, former director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), is a man who at one stage refused to support the use of condoms during the Aids crisis, insisting instead on sexual abstinence.

The CDC was slow to react to the news coming out of China and fluffed the development of a Covid test, again putting the US vital weeks behind the virus. Trump was largely oblivious to the incompetence he had instituted, mostly because he was incapable of hearing bad news and those who told him it tended not to stick around.

Very few government officials figures emerge with their reputations enhanced, yet some of them were in a genuine quandary. When your country is the midst of a rampaging pandemic, what do you do? Resign and whatever influence you might have is lost. Stay and you‚Äôre subsumed into the chaos and madness that Trump created all about him.

Wright is not unsympathetic to Deborah Birx, the former White House coronavirus response coordinator who featured in the excruciating news clip when Trump sought her agreement that injecting disinfectant might be the means of repelling infection. She doggedly tried to disseminate the message of social distancing, even as Trump insisted on holding virus-spreading political rallies.

And Matt Pottinger, the former deputy national security adviser, also fought a rearguard battle against those in charge. But this is not a book of heroes, apart perhaps from Barney Graham, the chief architect of both the Moderna and Pfizer vaccines. Instead, it‚Äôs a story about hubris and division, complacency and insularity, but most of all precariousness.

‚ÄúCovid-19,‚Äù writes Wright, ‚Äúis a harbinger.‚Äù He does not rule out the possibility that the virus accidentally escaped from one of the two labs in Wuhan that research bat coronaviruses. But even if it was not directly developed by humankind, it is very likely the result of human activity ‚Äì intensive animal farming, encroachment on natural preserves and the effects of the climate crisis.

Human ingenuity has provided us with the vaccines that may yet bring this pandemic under control. But there is no reason to assume that we will be so fortunate next time.

‚Ä¢ The Plague Year: America in the Time of Covid by Lawrence Wright is published by Allen Lane (¬£20). To support the Guardian go to guardianbookshop.com. Delivery charges may apply

results.webTitle: The best drive-through cinemas in the UK this summer

fields.headline: The best drive-through cinemas in the UK this summer
fields.standfirst: From Manchester‚Äôs Secret City to Glasgow‚Äôs Prestwick Airport, the silver screen takes a trip to the great outdoors
fields.trailText: From Manchester‚Äôs Secret City to Glasgow‚Äôs Prestwick Airport, the silver screen takes a trip to the great outdoors
fields.body:
Between the travel restrictions, social distancing, badly ventilated spaces indoors and weather outdoors, we are not exactly shaping up for a great British summer. The silver lining you seek could be the silver screen. Drive-in and outdoor cinemas are looking like the best of several worlds: you‚Äôre getting out of the house but not necessarily out of your car, you‚Äôre together with other people yet reassuringly separate. At the movies you can go anywhere you want, from Edwardian Britain to Wakanda ‚Äì for less than the price of a PCR swab test.

Related: The Guide: Staying In ‚Äì sign up for our home entertainment tips

The deal and the programming are similar at most drive-ins, but things to check include whether prices are per car or per person, how the sound is delivered ‚Äì via headphones, car radio or in-car speaker ‚Äì the screen size, ticket transferability and, of course, the catering.

Around London, The Alfresco Theatre prides itself on its gourmet food options, and has film and other live entertainment in St Albans (2 to 6 June) and Syon Park, Brentford (9 to 13 June). The Rooftop Film Club has drive-in cinemas at Alexandra Palace, Brent Cross and Sandown Park, as well as its actual rooftop venues in Peckham and Stratford. And The Drive In (to 30 June) has recent releases at Troubadour Meridian Water, N18.

Heading north, Manchester‚Äôs Secret City (to 6 June) has screenings every night, including a decent horror selection. The Luna Drive In Cinema has screenings in the grounds of Leeds‚Äô Harewood House throughout June. The Great British Drive In is at Stafford‚Äôs Sandon Hall till next weekend, and Wirral has the Woodside Drive In (to 27 Jun). Nightflix has six drive-ins including Milton Keynes, Hartlepool, Colchester and Luton Airport.

In Scotland, this weekend @ the Flix is at Glasgow‚Äôs Prestwick Airport, while Hopetoun House near Edinburgh has Harry Potter and Batman movies.

Around the south, later in the summer there is Loxwood Drive-In in West Sussex (17 July to 1 August). Or, for an atmospheric location, the clifftop Wavelength Drive-In (16 July to 5 September) near Newquay, Cornwall takes some beating. The programme is fittingly sea- and surf-centric.

Alternatively, for a car-free experience, Hideaway Cinema (to 19 September) visits venues, starting in Wetherby this week and including London‚Äôs Kew Gardens and Hampstead Heath, Norfolk‚Äôs Holkham Hall and more. Adventure Cinema (to 26 September) has outdoor screenings in scores of locations. And the well-established Luna Cinema (to 3 October) will be at stately and scenic locations nationwide.

Or, for something really different, try London‚Äôs float-in Openaire Cinema (2 to 27 June), where you can watch movies from a boat in Paddington Basin ‚Äì including, of course, Jaws.

fields.headline: An everyday story of US healthcare ‚Äì or how a visit to the ER can cost you $10,000
fields.standfirst: The fear of dying in New York was uppermost in my mind as my bruised foot swelled and turned black: I could never afford it
fields.trailText: The fear of dying in New York was uppermost in my mind as my bruised foot swelled: I could never afford it, says Guardian columnist Emma Brockes
fields.body:
I had dropped my kids off at school and was lifting one of their scooters, when I turned sharply and felt something ping in my foot. It wasn‚Äôt much; a bad cramp, I thought, more painful than usual, which would probably wear off by the time I got home. I limped back to my apartment, took painkillers and put it on ice. By the next morning, the foot had begun to turn black. By the evening, the flesh was rising like dough. ‚ÄúEw,‚Äù said a friend, when I showed it to her that night. ‚ÄúYou need a pedicure. Also: you need to see a doctor right now.‚Äù

It‚Äôs either laziness, Britishness, or a strain of my general belief in denial, but in most circumstances I‚Äôd rather suffer than bother the doctor. In the US, this impulse is compounded by the knowledge that, however much you spend on health insurance, even the smallest engagement with the medical establishment will result in a cascade of bills. I‚Äôm still fighting with my insurers over a $1,000 charge from last summer.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôll be fine,‚Äù I said, and an hour later, when it wasn‚Äôt ‚Äì the skin was now purple and gently contoured like foam ‚Äì booked a 10pm video appointment with a podiatrist. He logged on via his phone from what seemed to be the parking lot of a restaurant in Long Island. ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs all this?‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúDo you really need this appointment?‚Äù I showed him the foot. He squinted at the screen, crossed the lot and got into his car, where he turned on the light and squinted again. ‚ÄúOK, I don‚Äôt want panic you, but you need to seek emergency care right away.‚Äù My friend, meanwhile, had sent a photo of the foot to her brother in California, who is a doctor and also very much her brother. ‚ÄúEw, she needs a pedicure,‚Äù he replied. ‚ÄúNo one needs to see that. Also, that could be a blood clot, she needs to get to the ER.‚Äù

I left my kids with my friend and got in a taxi. ‚ÄúHow bad is a blood clot?‚Äù I‚Äôd asked my friend‚Äôs brother before leaving, and he‚Äôd reassured me it was no big deal as long as it didn‚Äôt detach. ‚ÄúThen what?‚Äù ‚ÄúYou‚Äôll die instantly.‚Äù This was concerning, particularly since the solution, he said, was ‚Äúnot to jiggle the leg‚Äù, but at that point my fears lay elsewhere. It‚Äôs expensive to die in New York, and as we crossed Central Park, I rang my insurers to get pre-authorisation (a promise with approximately the value of Neville Chamberlain‚Äôs piece of paper, but you may as well try.)

Then I rang my friend Oliver. It‚Äôs curious to me now, what surfaced in that moment. ‚ÄúCan you make sure, if anything happens, that you take the girls to England,‚Äù I asked, as he scrambled to catch up. ‚ÄúWhat? Are you near the hospital? How far off are you?‚Äù ‚ÄúMake sure they know about England,‚Äù I repeated. ‚ÄúTake them for the summer, on holiday, to England.‚Äù I sounded mad. It‚Äôs amazing, looking back, that I didn‚Äôt mention the Isle of Wight, and which hotel they should stay at. ‚ÄúOK, but just let me know when you get to the hospital,‚Äù he said.

The ER was half-empty. I have always wondered whether, in an emergency, my personality would undergo an exciting change, converted in the heat of the moment from a sort of vaguely up-myself diffidence to something more thrusting and American. Now I know. ‚ÄúHow are you, how can we help?‚Äù said the check-in clerk and reflexively I replied, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm fine.‚Äù For five minutes, I sat in the waiting room wondering if I was about to keel over and should be raising more alarm. Another five minutes passed, and the triage nurse came over. Even delivered in my apologetic, half-assed fashion, the words ‚Äúsuspected blood clot‚Äù had an immediate effect and I was sent straight through to the doctor.

It wasn‚Äôt a blood clot. It wasn‚Äôt a broken bone, either. No one that night could figure out what it was, except maybe a rip in the tendon, although they were very thorough and drew blood to rule out the possibility of low platelets. I don‚Äôt know what lesson to extract from all this, either, other than something reassuring about consistency of character.

Mainly, I‚Äôm aware, with weary resignation, that although the swelling has gone down and the foot is definitely on the mend, in other ways this is just the beginning. After an ultrasound, X-ray, blood test and patient transport all over New York‚Äôs premier hospital, I‚Äôm waiting for the inevitable $10,000 bill and the hours I will spend on the phone to contest it. It‚Äôs the story of American healthcare; the real pain starts now.

  • Emma Brockes is a Guardian columnist

fields.headline: Asian-Australian Labor members say Michael Daley hasn‚Äôt learned from ‚ÄòAsians with PhDs‚Äô comments
fields.standfirst: Eighteen people have signed a joint statement opposing the former NSW Labor leader‚Äôs bid to return to the top job, saying it would harm the party‚Äôs vote in multicultural communities
fields.trailText: Eighteen people have signed a joint statement opposing the former NSW Labor leader‚Äôs bid to return to the top job, saying it would harm the party‚Äôs vote in multicultural communities
fields.body:
Nearly 20 Asian-Australian Labor party members, including three current councillors, have signed a statement opposing Michael Daley‚Äôs bid to return as New South Wales Labor leader, saying he had failed to adequately learn from his 2019 comments about ‚ÄúAsians with PhDs‚Äù.

Daley, who led Labor to the 2019 state election, was widely criticised when footage emerged of him saying that ‚Äúyoung people from typically Asia with PhDs‚Äù were replacing ‚Äúour young children‚Äô‚Äô.

On Sunday, Daley announced that he would seek to return as leader after the resignation of Jodi McKay on Friday.

Asked about his 2019 comments, Daley said there was ‚Äúno point denying I made a few mistakes‚Äù.

Related: Jodi McKay resigns as NSW Labor leader to give party ‚Äòbest opportunity to heal‚Äô

‚ÄúI‚Äôve learned from my mistakes the hard way and I‚Äôve thought about them more than you could imagine,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúSome of the things that I said and did in that campaign, I can guarantee you will never happen again.‚Äù

But Kun Huang, a councillor at the Cumberland City Council in western Sydney, said that Daley‚Äôs comments on Sunday showed he had not ‚Äúlearned from the past‚Äù, and this would harm Labor‚Äôs vote in multicultural electorates.

Eighteen members of NSW Labor, including councillor Ernest Chan from Burwood Council and councillor Suman Saha, also from Cumberland City Council, have co-signed a statement opposing Daley‚Äôs leadership tilt.

The statement said Daley‚Äôs 2019 comments ‚Äúdamaged Labor‚Äôs credibility and trust with Asian-Australians‚Äù and a second Daley leadership would ‚Äúundermine our electoral potential and cause further division in the multicultural communities we represent‚Äù.

Daley said at the time: ‚ÄúOur young children will flee and who are they being replaced with? They are being replaced by young people from typically Asia with PhDs ‚Ä¶ our kids are moving out and foreigners are moving in and taking their jobs.‚Äù

He added: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not a bad thing because Asian kids are coming to work here, it‚Äôs a bad thing because I‚Äôd like my daughter to live in Maroubra rather than St Kilda.‚Äù

He later told media he was ‚Äúreferring to housing affordability in Sydney‚Äù.

But Huang said Daley‚Äôs comments about jobs and housing were not backed up with any evidence.

‚ÄúThere is no data to show that all the jobs are being taken by ‚ÄòAsians with PhDs‚Äô,‚Äù he told Guardian Australia. ‚ÄúIf you look at it, in senior management positions, there is a lack of diversity.‚Äù

Huang said that in Daley‚Äôs responses to questions on Sunday about the comments, he did not explain what was wrong about them.

‚ÄúIn his comments on Sunday he basically said: ‚ÄòI have learned from the past, I regret the things I have said. I have learned from my mistake.‚Äô But he never pointed out what he had learned. Nor has he pointed out what was the mistake.

‚ÄúLooking back at the past 12 months, we have been accused of stealing the [personal protective equipment] and stealing milk powder, and accused of being the reason property prices are going up.‚Äù

Osmond Chiu, a NSW Labor member and researcher at the Per Capita thinktank, said while the focus had been on Labor‚Äôs issues in the Hunter region, the party was also in danger of losing votes in multicultural seats.

‚ÄúThere has been a lot of focus on seats like the Hunter ‚Ä¶ but given reports that [federal seats] Greenway and Parramatta will be target seats for the Coalition, it is important that Labor takes multicultural seats seriously,‚Äô‚Äô he said. ‚ÄúIt is an electoral imperative if it wants to hold government.‚Äù

Chiu said that Labor‚Äôs support in those seats had been taken for granted.

He seems to be reflecting on the impacts of his actions on his own political career

Osmond Chiu, Labor party member

‚ÄúPeople are forgetting about them, because a lot of these seats have historically been held by Labor,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúThere has been a lot of commentary about Labor‚Äôs loss of blue-collar and regional voters, and it is in the media every day. But we don‚Äôt have anybody talking about this other issue. It was flagged in the Labor party 2019 state and federal reviews, but it hasn‚Äôt seen as much airtime.

‚ÄúThere aren‚Äôt as many voices from culturally diverse backgrounds discussing it in Australian politics. We don‚Äôt have an MP talking about it. We have an MP talking about the Hunter constantly.‚Äù

Daley‚Äôs opponent for the Labor leadership is Kogarah MP Chris Minns, who also challenged McKay in 2019.

Chiu said the statement against Daley was not factionally motivated, pointing out that he voted against Minns, and for McKay, in the 2019 NSW Labor leadership contest.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not going along traditional factional lines,‚Äù he said. He added that the leadership contest itself ‚Äúseems to be based on feelings about [NSW Labor headquarters] Sussex Street.‚Äù

Chiu said he was willing to vote for Daley if he did adequately apologise.

‚ÄúI would reconsider it if he can show contrition and that he genuinely gets it ‚Äì I am always happy for people to learn from their mistakes,‚Äù he said.

‚Äú[But] I think the last 24 hours has shown that Daley hasn‚Äôt really learned from those mistakes.

‚ÄúHe seems to be reflecting on the impacts of his actions on his own political career ‚Ä¶ He hasn‚Äôt demonstrated why he understands what he said was so hurtful and racist ‚Ä¶ he framed people of Asian heritage as an other, that was not really Australian.

‚ÄúHe has had two years to reflect on what he said. And he still couldn‚Äôt get it right.‚Äù

fields.headline: ‚ÄòA kind of rat with thorns‚Äô: the comic book busting myths about the Madras hedgehog
fields.standfirst: The elusive nocturnal creature is rarely seen in Tamil Nadu. One ecologist has made it his mission to spread the word through colourful adventures
fields.trailText: The elusive nocturnal creature is rarely seen in Tamil Nadu. One ecologist has made it his mission to spread the word through colourful adventures
fields.body:
The brightly coloured panels of Brawin Kumar‚Äôs comic book tell the story of how two children rescue a hedgehog from an unlicensed medicine man. The mother hedgehog is delighted to be reunited with her little one, as she has lost most of her offspring to road traffic.

Kumar, an Indian researcher and ecologist, came up with the idea of writing the book in Tamil to create awareness among children who live in and around the Madras hedgehog‚Äôs habitat. Many of those children will never have seen the nocturnal creature, which, unlike the British hedgehog, aestivates (lies in a state of torpor or dormancy) in the summer instead of hibernating in the winter.

Kumar‚Äôs first encounter with the Madras hedgehog (Paraechinus nudiventris), also known as the bare-bellied hedgehog, came in 2013, while he was doing fieldwork with the Zoo Outreach Organization. In a small town near Tirunelveli in Tamil Nadu, he heard stories about a kind of rat with thorns that had been spotted on nearby farmland and found dead in the road.

It took several visits to the town before he finally saw one, curled into a ball of spines under a bush and looking like a small bunch of twigs, he recalls.

‚ÄúLittle in India is known about the behaviour of these solitary and elusive animals and they are not even mentioned in folk tales,‚Äù says Kumar.

‚ÄúThey are called mul eli in Tamil ‚Äì mul meaning thorn, and eli which means rat. An adult can weigh up to 300 grams,‚Äù he adds.

The Madras hedgehog is endemic to southern India and is one of three species of hedgehog found in the country, and 17 worldwide. The Madras hedgehog lives in the dry and semi-arid lands of Coimbatore, Tirunelveli, Kanyakumari and Thoothukudi (formerly Tuticorin).

Inspired by that first encounter, Kumar started to study the hedgehogs. Local newspaper reports about sightings and conservation groups were good sources, and people also shared images from camera traps. He compiled extensive data with the help of questionnaires. His fieldwork identified 136 places across 16 districts where the hedgehogs were found.

When schools reopen after the pandemic, I will start reaching out to more in the hedgehog‚Äôs habitat areas

Brawin Kumar, ecologist

In 2018, he and his fellow researchers published a paper based on their findings. They found that the creatures made their homes not only in arid areas but in other habitats, such as pasture and grasslands, towns and sand dunes. They also found from analysing their droppings that, besides insects, the hedgehogs also ate grass and plant material and were omnivores. ‚ÄúI even found many of them under street lights, because they are insect-eating and this is where they find their food,‚Äù says Kumar.

Though the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) places the Madras hedgehog in the ‚Äúleast concern‚Äù category, in the past two decades the population has declined drastically due to changes in habitat and being hunted for meat, traditional medicine and as pets. ‚ÄúThe nomadic Narikurava community collect and trade in these animals. Many shops in Nagercoil sell hedgehog oil, even now,‚Äù says Kumar. ‚ÄúHedgehog spines are dried and used as ‚Äòmedicine‚Äô for whooping cough, arthritis and other ailments.‚Äù

Like their counterparts around the world, they are also susceptible to traffic. ‚ÄúThese tiny creatures head to tarred roads during the monsoons to try to catch the sun, and become road kills,‚Äù says Kumar.

Kumar and his team have recently submitted a policy document to the Tamil Nadu government calling for the conservation of the Madras hedgehog. Meanwhile, Kumar‚Äôs collaboration with his artist friend Venkatesh Babu to create the 20-page comic book Mullikkaattu Ithigaasam (Legend of the Scrub Forest) is helping to educate a new generation about these tiny creatures.

‚ÄúI realised that today‚Äôs kids don‚Äôt know anything about local animals like this one, and there is no mention in any school textbooks. That‚Äôs why I created the comic book,‚Äù says Kumar.

Related: Leaf blowers and beating branches: the fight to stop India‚Äôs forest fires

‚ÄúBabu is basically a cartoonist who loves nature and frequently conducts wildlife-related programmes in schools in south Tamil Nadu.‚Äù

In 2018, Kumar started distributing the book in a few schools in southern Tamil Nadu and was overwhelmed by the response. ‚ÄúWhen schools reopen after the pandemic, I will start reaching out to more in the hedgehog‚Äôs habitat areas to make people aware that these insect-eating creatures are actually a friend of the farmer. We are also preparing more kits with posters, booklets, stickers and colouring books.

‚ÄúResearchers and local NGOs have to work together to save these little creatures before they become extinct, and I think by appealing through the comic book to the next generation, their interest will be kindled,‚Äù says Kumar.

fields.headline: Ahead of the curd: how the dairy industry is tackling climate change
fields.standfirst: It‚Äôs never been more important that we build a climate-resilient dairy industry to keep local products such as milk, butter and cheese on Australian tables. Some dairy farmers have been championing sustainable practices for decades.
fields.trailText: It‚Äôs never been more important that we build a climate-resilient dairy industry to keep local products such as milk, butter and cheese on Australian tables. Some dairy farmers have been championing sustainable practices for decades.
fields.body:
Between the salty far-south coast of New South Wales and the town of Bega, the Jelgowry dairy farm at Jellat Jellat is well acquainted with the impacts of a changing climate. It‚Äôs here on a flood plain that Philippa and Robert Russell graze 320 Illawarra Shorthorn, Friesian and Jersey cows on a mix of native pastures and annual rye-clover plantings, and milk the herd twice a day in their solar-powered dairy. ‚ÄúThe farm has been in the family since the 1850s. My husband was born here,‚Äù says Philippa Russell.

When Philippa and Robert took over the family business in the early 1980s, the farm was devoid of trees. ‚ÄúIn the 1800s, there was a big push for farmers to clear the land,‚Äù says Philippa. Those founding farmers soon upscaled from horse labour to steam-engine machinery, and the felling of timber continued for fuel. ‚ÄúIt gives you some idea of what we started with. We knew the farm needed to have a better balance and a more sustainable way of farming. It wasn‚Äôt going to happen unless we changed the methods of the past.‚Äù

To begin achieving that balance, the Russells decided on yearly plantings, and the farm now has over 35,000 trees and shrubs across its 220 hectares (550 acres). ‚ÄúWe have a better balance of insects and bird life, and the pastures do much better because they have protection from wind,‚Äù she says.

It‚Äôs also resulted in visible moisture retention in the soils, which has helped the Jelgowry farm to be more resilient in times of drought. ‚ÄúI believe that the plantings have helped and I think that‚Äôs why we have healthier pastures. We‚Äôre not irrigating quite so much. We‚Äôve fenced out gullies, so we‚Äôre slowing down the water. If we have a long dry spell, we can actually make things work a lot better now than how things were in 1980.‚Äù

  • The Russells decided on yearly plantings, and the farm now has over 35,000 trees and shrubs across its 220 hectares (550 acres).

With the UN Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) warning there are only 12 years to limit catastrophe, the need for climate action has become louder and more urgent. But dairy farmers like the Russells have had a head start, slowly building resilience throughout their almost 40-year tenure. ‚ÄúThe extreme weather events seem to be more common. We know that droughts and floods are always going to hurt, but you want to try to minimise that damage. We‚Äôve done this for so many years,‚Äù says Philippa.

‚ÄúDairy farmers have already seen the impacts of climate change and many businesses are making changes that are assisting them to adapt,‚Äù says Alison Kelly, Dairy Australia‚Äôs Lead ‚Äì Climate and Energy.

Today, 81 per cent of dairy farmers are safeguarding a portion of their land for conservation and biodiversity (up from 45 percent in 2015). It‚Äôs just one of the ways farmers and the dairy industry are working together to protect natural capital and address climate risk.

Despite having access to the Brogo Dam for irrigation (allocation has increased from 30 per cent in July 2018 to 65 per cent in February 2019 thanks to good rain), the Russells admit water is a constant challenge. The global average water footprint of milk is about 1,000 litres of water to every one litre of milk.

‚ÄúWe know it‚Äôs a very precious commodity and we can‚Äôt do dairying without it, so we‚Äôre very mindful of how we use it, when we use it and the cost of it,‚Äù says Philippa. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve seen the climate change. We had a 10-year drought in the 2000s. And I think that reinforced our belief that we should have a more sustainable farm. I think most people in the district woke up then because water was a big issue. And it still is.‚Äù

That 10-year-long millennium drought saw collaborative efforts between government, manufacturer Bega Cheese and local farmers to address water sustainability. And in 2004, thanks to initial funding from the federal government, the processor launched the Bega Environmental Management System (BEMS) sustainability assessment. This progressive pilot study was instrumental in implementing and quantifying the benefits of new environmental practices across water, effluent, nutrient management, fertiliser application and biodiversity. The Russells were among 20 farms participating in the study, and by 2015, 94 per cent of Bega‚Äôs farmers had engaged with the ongoing system.

Philippa says it‚Äôs been a combination of government funding and industry support that‚Äôs helped pave the way for them to invest in more sustainable methods on-farm.

  • While dairy processors have been working hard to minimise greenhouse gas emissions, the manufacturing space comprises five per cent of dairy‚Äôs total emissions, with 95 per cent produced on-farm.

‚ÄúWe analysed all our issues on-farm that were environmentally sensitive. There‚Äôs been some grant money to help us with fencing, tree planting, off-stream watering and effluent management,‚Äù says Philippa.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think there‚Äôd be as much done if the funding wasn‚Äôt there. It‚Äôs certainly been a benefit, not just to ourselves but many farms in the district.‚Äù

To improve environmental sustainability and financial viability, the dairy industry has committed to the IPCC‚Äôs below 2¬∞C target, which means reducing greenhouse gas emissions intensity by 30 per cent by 2030. While dairy processors have been working hard to minimise greenhouse gas emissions, the manufacturing space comprises five per cent of dairy‚Äôs total emissions, with 95 per cent produced on-farm.

Dairy Australia has developed tools like the Australian Dairy Carbon Calculator and the Dairy Climate Toolkit, so farmers can begin to quantify on-farm emissions and proactively identify strategies to adapt their farm systems for the future. ‚ÄúEnteric methane remains a high source of emissions on dairy farms and so will remain a focus for our research and development,‚Äù says Alison. ‚ÄúWork is currently being undertaken to review the last decades‚Äô Dairy Farm Monitor Project data to establish the reporting baseline for measuring against the on-farm greenhouse gas emissions intensity target.‚Äù

Going forward, Dairy Australia predicts it‚Äôll turn its attention to a scenario-based approach for assessing climate risk and researching technological options to reduce methane emissions from cows. ‚ÄúThere will be an increasing need for researchers and farm managers to identify and implement practices on-farm to reduce the loss of greenhouse gas emissions to the environment,‚Äù says Alison.

Philippa Russell says that farming sustainably is essential to keeping the farm going in the face of extreme climate variations. ‚ÄúReally we‚Äôre here to look after the land and to keep it going for another generation. We‚Äôre caretakers of the land. And if you don‚Äôt do the right thing for the land, then it‚Äôs not going to give you the return that you want and need. You‚Äôve got to look after the land you‚Äôre working with. You don‚Äôt get another shot at it,‚Äù Philippa says.
